Package work.teamteam.mock

Class Mockery

java.lang.Object
work.teamteam.mock.Mockery
public class Mockery
extends java.lang.Object
Mockery is a library for mocking classes when testing. Mocking can be used: * to create a fake version of classes you don't want to call during tests (e.g external apis) * to replace single methods via "spies" * to control the return value of methods for a class outside the tests scope * to record the number of times certain methods were called with given arguments

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes 
    Modifier and Type Class Description
    static interface  Mockery.Trackable
    Base interface to access all tracking data associated with a mock/spy

  • Method Details

    • clearCache

      public static void clearCache()

    • reset

      public static void reset()
      Resets all global state. Global state is used to simplify the api (i.e to mimic Mockito). In an API such as "when(foo.doesSomething(a, b)).thenReturn" there's no other clean way for the when call to get access to the method called (doesSomething) and the parameters (a, b).

    • mock

      public static <T> T mock​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
      Creates a new mock implementing the given class. Mocks provide a dummy implementation of the class, with every method returning a default value based on their return type (see Defaults.Impl).
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - class to implement
      Returns:
      an instance implementing clazz

    • mock

      public static <T> T mock​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz, boolean trackHistory)
      Creates a new mock implementing the given class. Mocks provide a dummy implementation of the class, with every method returning a default value based on their return type. This default is specified by "defaults"
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - class to implement
      trackHistory - whether to track history
      Returns:
      an instance implementing clazz

    • mock

      public static <T> T mock​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz, Defaults defaults)
      Creates a new mock implementing the given class. Mocks provide a dummy implementation of the class, with every method returning a default value based on their return type. This default is specified by "defaults"
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - class to implement
      defaults - lets you specify the default values (per class) returned when methods are called
      Returns:
      an instance implementing clazz

    • mock

      public static <T> T mock​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz, boolean trackHistory, Defaults defaults)
      Creates a new mock implementing the given class. Mocks provide a dummy implementation of the class, with every method returning a default value based on their return type. This default is specified by "defaults"
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - class to implement
      defaults - lets you specify the default values (per class) returned when methods are called
      trackHistory - whether to track history
      Returns:
      an instance implementing clazz

    • spy

      public static <T> T spy​(T impl)
      Creates a new spy around impl. With spies you can override methods and record their call count. Any method you don't override will invoke the equivalent method in impl.
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      impl - the object to wrap
      Returns:
      an instance spying on impl

    • spy

      public static <T> T spy​(T impl, boolean trackHistory)

    • spy

      public static <T> T spy​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz, java.lang.Object... args)
      Creates a new spy. This is equivalent to spy(new clazz(args...)). With spies you can override methods and record their call count. Any method you don't override will invoke the equivalent method in impl.
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class to spy on
      args - args to pass to the instance of clazz we're instanciating
      Returns:
      an instance spying on clazz

    • spy

      public static <T> T spy​(java.lang.Class<T> clazz, boolean trackHistory, java.lang.Object... args)
      Creates a new spy. This is equivalent to spy(new clazz(args...)). With spies you can override methods and record their call count. Any method you don't override will invoke the equivalent method in impl.
      Type Parameters:
      T - type of the class
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class to spy on
      trackHistory - whether to track history
      args - args to pass to the instance of clazz we're instanciating
      Returns:
      an instance spying on clazz

    • when

      public static <T> Mock<T> when​(T o)
      Used to override the return value of a specific method + arguments. e.g when(foo.doSomething(any(), eq("foo")).thenReturn(100); In this example whenever foo.doSomething(..., "foo") is called we will return 100. Any calls not matching the two predicates ("any()" and "eq("foo")") will return the default
      Type Parameters:
      T - return type of the method being configured
      Parameters:
      o - object to override. This is provided for convenience, we actually use the last called method of any mocked object.
      Returns:
      a Mock for specifying your overrides

    • verify

      public static <T> T verify​(T o, int numCalls)
      Used to verify the given method was called exactly "numCalls" times. This returns o, and the next method call will be verified. e.g verify(foo, 1).doSomething(any());
      Type Parameters:
      T - generic type of o
      Parameters:
      o - object we want to verify the next call of
      numCalls - number of times we expect the next method to have been called
      Returns:
      o

    • verify

      public static <T> T verify​(T o, java.util.function.IntPredicate predicate)
      Used to verify the given method was called N times. This returns o, and the next method call will be verified. e.g verify(foo, Times.le(1)).doSomething(any()); See Times for common predicates that can be used.
      Type Parameters:
      T - generic type of o
      Parameters:
      o - object we want to verify the next call of
      predicate - predicate that will be called with the number of times this method has been seen
      Returns:
      o

    • reset

      public static void reset​(java.lang.Object o)
      Resets internal state such as the method call history associated with the mock/spy o.
      Parameters:
      o - object to reset
